entry.title: Development of client-facing app in SAP BTP - Authentication and User management
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on the development of an SAPUI5 application in SAP BTP using SAP Business Application Studio. The idea is that this application will be deployed using SAP Build Workzone, Standard edition. This application acts like a simple portal where a small subset of the company's customers (~5 customers, which themselves are also companies) will need to access from outsite the organization where the app will be hosted. Based on the logged in user, the portal will display data regarding to the business partner that user represents (this I believe a mapping between the user and the BP code in SAP is enough). The Odata service itself is not that complex (in the sense that will retrieve sales data for the customer, so it's pretty much an Odata service that will retrieve data from sales tables like VBAK, VBAP, etc. For context, I'm working with a on-premise ECC EHP7 backend. An high level diagram of the development is as below:

 

‚ÄÉ

As I am fairly new to BTP Identity solutions, I believe that the main point here is regarding the expositure of this app in SAP BTP for people outside the organization (third party access). One of the requirements is that the management of the credentials for these customers would be done entirely on my organization's side, for better control: we would not want anyone with access to the app to request an user account there.

There are a handful of possibilites, but i'd like to understand what would be the best approaches (or at least an combination of approaches). I thought of the following approaches:

1) try to manage the authentication with a developed user service - besides being less safe, I believe this is not possible due to the security layet BTP itself has, so you'd need to have a valid user to authenticate with BTP before accessing the portal.

2) Use SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS alone), with its Local User Store and without both Self Service registration and Social Identity Providers - Users would be created by administrators, and the password sent to them, in a similar fashion to what's done with service keys for Integration Suite scenarios. Similar to the scenario in https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/business-to-business-scenario?locale=en-US, considering a single user per customer (or even https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/business-to-consumer-scenario?locale=en-US without the possibility of the user creating an access to themselves

3) Use SAP Cloud Identity Services (not only IAS) to manage the integration with the corporate identity provider of the organization i'm working (Microsoft Entra ID). I believe this can be more complex as we'd shift the control of the user maintenance to the organization's Identity Provider, so some sort of federation/trust would be required between SAP Cloud Identity Services and Entra ID.

 
This looks like a common (or at least, not very uncommon) scenario, so I would appreciate guidances or suggestions on the best path for this auth.
 
Thanks in Advance,
Erick Grilo.

entry.title: IAM for SAP Joule
entry.content:
üîê IAM for SAP Joule: Building Secure, Scalable AI Experiences
As organizations embrace SAP Joule and SAP Business AI, Identity and Access Management (IAM) becomes the backbone of secure and seamless integration across business applications. Here‚Äôs what you need to know:

‚úÖ Why IAM Matters for Joule
SAP Joule is more than a conversational AI‚Äîit connects processes and data across multiple SAP applications. To achieve this, robust IAM architecture ensures:
Cross-domain access without compromising security.
Consistent user experience across integrated apps.
Compliance with enterprise cybersecurity standards.

üîë Core IAM Components
SAP Cloud Identity Services
Joule uses these services as its user store, enabling centralized identity management and role-based access.
OpenID Connect (OIDC)
The recommended protocol for secure integration between Joule and SAP Business AI.
Role Mapping & Session Management
Content is exposed based on role names, and user-to-role assignments occur dynamically during sessions.

üõ† Integration Flow
Initial Setup: Configure Joule with SAP Cloud Identity Services.
Common Data Model (CDM): Define which Joule functions map to specific roles.
Cross-Application IAM: Once the first app integrates with Joule, subsequent apps reuse the same IAM patterns.

üåê Navigation & Access
SAP Joule leverages SAP Build Work Zone for unified navigation across applications, ensuring smooth transitions for end users.

üí° Why This Matters
IAM for Joule isn‚Äôt just about authentication‚Äîit‚Äôs about enabling secure, intelligent collaboration across SAP‚Äôs ecosystem. As AI becomes central to enterprise workflows, IAM ensures trust, compliance, and scalability.

üëâ What‚Äôs your take? How do you see IAM evolving as AI-driven platforms like Joule become mainstream?

entry.title: SAP IAS Implementation on an SAP ECC on premise and direct API endpoints.
entry.content:
Hello!

I have been working in the implementation of IAS for my SAP system. The goal is to protect UI5 applications with MFA. So far so good, when the user wants to log in, is redirected to the IAS login page, where MFA is enforced. After a successful logon the user is redirected back to the corresponding UI5 application.

As an example, let's assume I have a UI5 application where users go to create purchase orders, this works all fine as long as you do it the legit way, but if I wanted to instead of using the UI5 application just identify the API endpoint to create purchase orders and then hit that directly using postman for example, it would let me do it just fine as long as I put my user id and password in the request headers.

To me this kind of defeats the purpose of MFA, but I am not sure if this is by design or I am missing something. Has anyone been here before? Is there something additional I need to do to enforce MFA on API endpoints?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: EntraID Token Propagation via SAP Approuter for Azure destinations?
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

My question is related to an integration case, where I want to privately integrate data from a SAP backend to an Azure Storage account.

Situation: Write Data from the backend (S/4) via Integration Suite to a private Storage account. I am using SAP private link service (PLS) to be able to reach the private endpoint of the azure storage account, the destination call must be made via an SAP approuter, as there is no direct way of calling the PLS destination directly in SAP Integration Suite.

Problem: Even though the approuter supports token propagation, i could not figure out a way of chaining the propagation, so that I authenticate at the Approuter protected by Cloud IAS (with MS Entra as corp. IdP), translate the token to back to the correct format, that is then presented to the Storage account. The issue lies in the audience claim of the JWT token. For authenticating against the storage account the scope has to match the targeted azure resource (https://storage.azure.com in this case), the claim required by the approuter, however, is the client id of the Cloud IAS application. 

Question(s): Is this integration case even supported by SAP Cloud IAS / MS Entra Token Propagation in combination with using the SAP approuter? My assumption was, since all resources are protected by the same Entra Id tenant, it must be possible to propagate/translate the token to the respective resources?

Another interesting questions would be, if there is a planned feature to support Private Link Service directly via Integration Suite instead of the work-around via the approuter?


Thanks a lot in advance for any response. 

Best Regards 
Matthias

At first we need to enable the 2 things successfully like 

1. Cloud Identity Services

2. SAP Build Work Zone

In the very first step is to click the Create option in your Instances and Subscriptions tab

In this New Instance Window click on Cloud Identity Services then Plan will be default

Service: Cloud Identity Services

Plan: default

Once you done click on Create in the Bottom of the Screen

Once you have create the above service successfully then we need to move on to the Users tab then click on user we need and click on Assign Role Collection

Once you click on that the Assign Role Collection Dialogue will open then we need to search and assign the roles in below

Cloud Connector Administrator, Connectivity and Destination Administrator, Subaccount Service Administrator, Subaccount Viewer

Once you have assigned the role it will looks like below

After completing the above step, please check your email for a message regarding identity authentication. Click the link provided in the email to activate it and verify your account.

 

 

Once you click on the link the Cloud Identity service will open if not just go the Cloud Identity service which was in your BTP Instance and service

 

 

Once you have verified through mail move to the Instances and Subscriptions tab click on Cloud Identity then click Go to Application

 

Once you have done you will see this page Cloud Identity Services in this click on User Management

After clicking the User Management verify the user credentials here

Then move on the Trust Configuration Part under the Security then click on Establish Trust the configure Tenant pop up will open

In this select the Default value 

In this choose Domain option choose option end with ‚Äòtrail-accound.ondemand.com‚Äô

Then click on create to sap build work zone

With this you can go for standard subscription plan

We have successfully activated the sap Build work zone

 

Then will check on HTML5 Applications tab you can see HTML5 application now allow to add application here, Thank for Reading!

entry.title: How to identify a Corporate IDP in the URL when using the DynamicIdentityProvider in SAP AppRouter
entry.content:
We are in the process of building a custom application which will be used by both employees and customers and therefore want to have each group authenticate against their respective Corporate IDP.

The custom CAP application is deployed into a BTP subacccount which has been configured with the trust to the SAP Cloud Identity Service (lets call it "SAP CIS External") instance intended specifically for this externally facing application.  We have a separate SAP Cloud Identity Service (lets call it "SAP CIS Internal") which is used for employee authentication by this application and other applications including Fiori for internal use only.

The "SAP CIS External" has 2 Corporate IDPs configured:

  1. ADFS - to be used for authenticating external customers. Configured as the default 'Corporate IDP'
  2. "SAP CIS Internal" - to be used for authenticating employees

Based on the following documentation, I understand that I should be able to use a URL to direct authentication to "SAP CIS Internal" as the 'alternate' Corporate IDP,  thus not using the default Corporate IDP configured. This would allow customers to use the 'default' Corporate IDP while internal employees will be provided a specific URL for them to access this application using our internal IDP.

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/environment-variables?locale=en-US
    • Refer: 'DYNAMIC_IDENTITY_PROVIDER' Environment variable
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/create-url-to-access-saml-oidc-application-with-specific-identity-provider
  • https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/approuter#dynamic-identity-provider-configuration

Questions:

  1. What is the name of the 'Corporate IDP' I should be using for the URI parameter 'sap_idp'?
    • Based on the documentation it states that the 'Display Name' should not be used, but there is no alternative name. Neither work anyway.
    • The examples provided show the usage of a protocol and domain (eg. sap_idp=https://corp_idp_2.mydomain.com) but does not indicate how to source this value. Multiple values have been tested and do not work.
  2. How should the Dynamic Identity Provider setting be configured as my current configuration is not working?
    1. Configured the 'route' in our AppRouter to have the setting =>  "dynamicIdentityProvider": true
    2. Set the environment variable "DYNAMIC_IDENTITY_PROVIDER" in the AppRouter CAP in subaccount and space to have a value of => true

entry.title: IAS service binding auto-rotates X.509
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are using IAS with a Cloud Foundry application, and we provision IAS users through the User Management REST API https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/user-management-rest-api.

Our IAS instance allows X.509 credentials, and the application uses the X.509 certificate automatically generated in the service binding.

During deployment, Cloud Foundry recreates the binding, and we consistently observe the following:

Behaviour

Every time the service binding is recreated, IAS issues a new X.509 certificate, even when the previous one has not expired.

When the certificate is rotated, IAS automatically disables ‚ÄúAPI Access for application users‚Äù, and the User Management REST API stops working until we manually re-enable it.

The certificate rotation and permission toggle happen even if nothing in the IAS configuration changed.

Questions

Is this the expected behaviour in IAS/Cloud Foundry? Does IAS always regenerate a new X.509 credential whenever a CF binding is recreated?

If this is expected, what is the recommended way to avoid breaking the User Management REST API during deployments? Should we avoid certificate-based credentials for apps that use the User Management API?

Goal

We want to prevent situations where the User Management REST API suddenly stops working after a deployment.

Any guidance, recommended patterns, or confirmations of expected behaviour would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud session cookies remain after corporate IdP logout
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community!

currently we are facing an issue with our SAP Analytics Cloud, or rather the session management of the product. We created different stories in our SAC which we embedded in our corporate environment so our customers and employees can use them. This is done via iFrame. 

Our SAC has an Cloud Identity Instance as an IdP configured while the Cloud Identity Instance uses a Microsoft based corporate IdP where all SSO requests are forwarded. 

Now for the actual issue: After user A logs initiates a logoff in the corporate environment the session is terminated and the user is forwared to the login page again. But if user B does a login the SAC still has the session cookes from user A active and no further authentication flow is triggered. This means that user B works with the SAC user A until the browser is actually closed (since that is the cookie lifetime) 

We were under the impression that when the corporate IdP terminates the session, the Cloud Identity Service "tells" the Analytics Cloud to delete the session + cookies as well. 

Does anybody have a similar experience with SAC integrations via iFrame?

entry.title: Onboarding 2.0 IAS/IPS provisioning: Hire gets two provisioning emails if rehire
entry.content:
Hello,

We have completed our IAS/IPS Tenant Migration and activated the ‚Äòreal-time sync‚Äô functionality for our Onboarding 2.0 application. In addition, we have the switch ‚ÄúRetain Onboarding Username for Rehire on Old Employment‚Äù active in Onboarding General Settings.

Prior to the IAS/IPS Tenant migration and the real-time sync, the following process took place:

  1. The Review New Hire Data step is completed by HR. IPS Read Job creates Onboarding credentials and provisioning email is sent from IAS.
  2. Hire enters SSN/DOB into Onboarding. This triggers the Rehire Validation check assuming the hire is a rehire.
  3. HR completes the Rehire Validation check and selects ‚ÄúRehire with Old Employment‚Äù.
  4. Existing IAS username and password is retained by the hire. They do not get a second email from IAS. A rehire email is sent from Email Services. If they are still logged into ONB 2.0, they can even refresh their browser to continue Onboarding.
  5. Rehire completes their Onboarding tasks with their existing IAS credentials.

Now, with the IAS/IPS tenant migration and the real-time sync, below the new process:

  1. Steps 1-3 above are the same.
  2. Hire now gets a second Hire/Welcome email from IAS. They are required to re-authenticate and specify a new password. The old password no longer works.
  3. Rehire completes their Onboarding tasks with their new IAS credentials.

Ideally, we‚Äôd love the process to retain the Onboardee‚Äôs prior IAS credentials, even with the real-time sync and the tenant migration in place. Has anyone solved this? 

Regards,

Jay Crowley
